flood.title: Flash Flood
flood.description: Learn how to stay safe during a flash flood, protect your property from damage, and take the right steps to recover quickly once the water recedes.

flood1.label: Heavy Rainfall
flood1.text: Intense, short-duration downpours overwhelm drains and waterways, causing water levels to rise rapidly.

flood2.label: Blocked Drains
flood2.text: Leaves, litter, and silt clog drains and culverts, trapping runoff and backing water onto streets and homes.

flood3.label: Deforestation
flood3.text: Loss of trees and ground cover reduces infiltration and soil stability, speeding runoff and sending debris into waterways.

flood4.label: Urbanization
flood4.text: Concrete and asphalt limit absorption, channeling large volumes of rain into drainage systems that can overflow.

flood5.label: Low-Lying Terrain
flood5.text: Areas near rivers, canals, or below surrounding land collect runoff and are more prone to rapid inundation.

items.floodPB1: Always stay informed by news or alerts on your phone.
items.floodPB2: Organize an emergency bag with essentials & first-aid.
items.floodPB3: Know your evacuation plan & safe alternate routes.
items.floodPB4: Follow instructions & leave before flooding starts.

items.floodSD1: Do NOT walk or drive in flood water.
items.floodSD2: Get to higher ground as soon as possible.
items.floodSD3: Follow all evacuation instructions and orders.

items.floodRA2: Stay away from fallen power lines.
items.floodRA3: Do NOT return home or to disaster areas until they are declared safe.
items.floodRA4: When back home, clean and disinfect surfaces and items.

pub.title: PUB Flood Advisory
pub.desc: Stay informed on how PUB mitigates flood risks in Singapore and follow their essential flood safety tips.

st.title: Monsoon Road Safety
st.desc: Tips for motorists to navigate safely during heavy rain and monsoon surges, reducing accident risks.

hch.title: Post-Flood Cleanup Tips
hch.desc: Get practical guidance on cleaning and restoring your home after a flash flood.

laminar.title: Flood Barrier Solutions
laminar.desc: Explore practical flood protection products and solutions designed for Singapore’s environment.

haze.title: Haze (PM2.5)
haze.description: Learn how to protect yourself and your family during haze episodes. Understand the health risks of PM2.5, take preventive measures, and know how to deal with haze events.

haze1.label: Forest Fires
haze1.text: Regional biomass burning emits smoke and fine particles that travel long distances.

haze2.label: Transboundary Pollution
haze2.text: Winds transport pollutants from neighboring regions into local airspace.

haze3.label: Dry Weather
haze3.text: Dry spells allow smoke to persist and reduce natural particulate wash-out by rain.

haze4.label: Urbanization
haze4.text: Vehicle and industrial emissions add to background PM2.5 during haze periods.

haze5.label: Stagnant Air
haze5.text: Weak winds and temperature inversions trap pollutants near the ground.

items.haze-01: Monitor haze forecasts and PSI/PM2.5 readings daily.
items.haze-02: Stock up on N95 masks and store them in a clean, dry place.
items.haze-03: Purchase and maintain air purifiers with HEPA filters.
items.haze-04: Seal gaps in doors and windows to reduce indoor smoke entry.

items.haze-05: Limit outdoor activities, especially for those with health issues.
items.haze-06: Wear a properly fitted N95 mask when outdoors.
items.haze-07: Stay hydrated and avoid strenuous outdoor exercise.
items.haze-08: Use eye drops and nasal saline spray to ease irritation.

items.haze-09: Open windows and doors to air out your home when air quality improves.
items.haze-10: Clean floors and surfaces to remove deposited dust particles.
items.haze-11: Replace or clean air purifier filters after the haze episode.
items.haze-12: Follow up with a doctor if symptoms persist.

nea.title: Managing Haze in Singapore
nea.desc: Learn how Singapore monitors air quality, manages transboundary haze, and implements measures to reduce exposure.

healthhub.title: Protect Yourself Against Haze
healthhub.desc: Practical steps to safeguard your health during haze periods, including mask usage and home air quality tips.

mom.title: Workplace Safety During Haze
mom.desc: Guidelines for employers and workers to stay safe, from adjusting outdoor work to providing protective equipment.

st.title: 5 Ways to Protect Yourself
st.desc: Quick lifestyle tips to reduce haze health risks, from staying indoors to boosting indoor air quality.

mounte.title: Facts About Haze
mounte.desc: Understand the causes, effects, and prevention of haze, and learn how to manage related health issues.

dengue.title: Dengue Prevention
dengue.description: Learn how to protect yourself and your community from dengue fever, a mosquito-borne disease. Understand its causes, recognise symptoms early, and take proactive measures to prevent outbreaks.

dengue1.label: Stagnant Water
dengue1.text: Aedes mosquitoes breed in small pools—flower pots, pails, roof gutters, tray dishes.

dengue2.label: Humid Climate
dengue2.text: Warm, humid conditions speed up mosquito life cycles and virus replication.

dengue3.label: Poor Waste Mgmt.
dengue3.text: Discarded containers and clutter collect rainwater, creating breeding sites.

dengue4.label: Urban Density
dengue4.text: Close living quarters increase bite exposure and speed cluster spread.

dengue5.label: Infected Travellers
dengue5.text: Imported cases can seed local transmission when bitten by Aedes mosquitoes.

items.dengue-01: Remove stagnant water from flower pots, buckets, and trays.
items.dengue-02: Clear roof gutters and always ensure proper drainage.
items.dengue-03: Change water in vases, bowls, and birdbaths every 2 days.
items.dengue-04: Install window and door screens to block mosquitoes.

items.dengue-05: Sudden high fever lasting 2 to 7 days.
items.dengue-08: Nausea, vomiting, or loss of appetite.
items.dengue-09: Skin rash appearing a few days after fever starts.
items.dengue-10: Bleeding gums, persistent vomiting, abdominal pain.

items.dengue-11: Seek medical attention immediately if dengue is suspected.
items.dengue-12: Remember to drink plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration.
items.dengue-13: Rest well and avoid physical exertion until full recovery.
items.dengue-15: Use mosquito nets or repellents to avoid infecting others.
items.dengue-16: Follow up with healthcare providers for monitoring.

cgs.title: Block Dengue Campaign
cgs.desc: Get weekly tips from the Block Dengue campaign on how to keep your home and neighbourhood mosquito-free.

singhealth.title: Dengue Symptoms & Treatment
singhealth.desc: Understand the common signs of dengue and learn when and how medical care is required for safe recovery.

raffles.title: Dengue Fever Insights
raffles.desc: Learn how dengue spreads through Aedes mosquitoes, recognize its symptoms and stay informed to take early action.

storm.title: Thunderstorm
storm.description: Thunderstorms in Singapore can bring heavy rain, strong winds, lightning strikes, and flash floods. Learn how to protect yourself and reduce risks from lightning and wind damage.

storm1.label: Rising Warm Air
storm1.text: Heated surface air rises rapidly, forming towering cumulonimbus clouds.

storm2.label: High Moisture
storm2.text: Abundant humidity fuels cloud growth and intense rainfall.

storm3.label: Converging Winds
storm3.text: Sea breeze and monsoon flows collide, triggering strong updrafts.

storm4.label: Monsoon Seasons
storm4.text: Seasonal wind patterns enhance storm frequency and severity.

storm5.label: Temperature Differences
storm5.text: Sharp contrasts between air masses destabilize the atmosphere.

items.storm-01: Monitor weather forecasts and NEA lightning alerts.
items.storm-02: Secure loose items outdoors (plants, furniture, tools).
items.storm-03: Check drainage around your home to reduce flood risk.
items.storm-04: Avoid scheduling outdoor events during storm warnings.

items.storm-06: Stay away from open fields, tall trees, and metal poles.
items.storm-07: Avoid swimming pools, beaches, or any open water.
items.storm-08: Unplug electronics to prevent lightning damage.

items.storm-09: Check for and report fallen trees, damaged power lines, or flooding.
items.storm-10: Avoid touching electrical equipment until safe.

cdc.title: Lightning Safety Guidelines
cdc.desc: Learn essential lightning safety measures, including first-aid steps to help someone struck by lightning.

mom.title: Adverse Weather Response
mom.desc: Singapore's official WSH guidelines for managing risks during adverse weather; designed for safe workplace practices.

hyme.title: Lightning Risk Assessment
hyme.desc: Insight into how Singapore's built environments can be safeguarded from lightning.

wind.title: Strong Wind
wind.description: Learn how to stay safe, protect your surroundings, and reduce risks during periods of strong winds and gusty weather in Singapore.

wind1.label: Sumatra Squalls
wind1.text: Fast-moving storm lines from Sumatra can produce sudden, powerful gusts.

wind2.label: Monsoon Surges
wind2.text: Cool surges in the Northeast Monsoon bring sustained strong winds.

wind3.label: Tropical Storms
wind3.text: Regional cyclones influence pressure gradients and wind strength.

wind4.label: Downdraft Bursts
wind4.text: Thunderstorm downdrafts can create brief but damaging outflow winds.

wind5.label: Building Channeling
wind5.text: Urban canyons funnel airflow, locally amplifying wind speeds.

items.wind1: Park vehicles away from trees, lamp posts, and unstable structures.
items.wind2: Secure loose outdoor items like plant pots, laundry poles, and signage.
items.wind3: Close and lock windows and balcony doors.
items.wind4: Avoid scheduling outdoor activities in exposed areas.

items.wind5: Stay indoors and away from windows.
items.wind6: If outside, seek shelter in a sturdy building.
items.wind7: Avoid walking under large trees, power lines, or temp. structures.
items.wind8: Be alert for flying debris and the falling branches.

items.wind9: Clear debris safely—wear gloves and avoid sharp objects.
items.wind10: Inspect your property for damage & hazards like loose roof tiles.

met.title: Staying Safe in Strong Wind
met.desc: Practical guidance from the Met Office on protecting your home, safe travel, and staying secure during high wind events.

mss.title: Learn Weather Phenomena
mss.desc: Explore Singapore’s common weather hazards and understand how they form and affect daily life.

fire.title: Fire Safety
fire.description: Learn how to prevent fires, respond effectively in an emergency, and protect lives and property. Fires can start unexpectedly, but being prepared greatly reduces risks and saves lives.

fire1.label: Unattended Cooking
fire1.text: Grease and oil ignite quickly when left heating without supervision.

fire2.label: Overloaded Sockets
fire2.text: Too many devices on a power strip can overheat wiring and outlets.

fire3.label: Faulty Wiring
fire3.text: Damaged cables or loose connections can arc and start a blaze.

fire4.label: Open Flames
fire4.text: Candles, incense, or lighters near flammables cause accidental ignition.

fire5.label: Flammable Storage
fire5.text: Improperly stored solvents or aerosols increase fire intensity.

items.fire1: Install and maintain smoke detectors in key areas of your home.
items.fire2: Keep fire extinguishers accessible and know how to use them.
items.fire3: Avoid overloading power points and use certified electrical products.
items.fire4: Store flammable items in cool, ventilated spaces away from heat.

items.fire5: Stay Calm – Alert others and call 995 immediately.
items.fire6: If smoke is present, stay low to avoid inhaling toxic fumes.
items.fire7: Use a wet cloth to cover your nose and mouth.

items.fire9: Wait for SCDF clearance before re-entering premises.
items.fire10: Arrange professional inspection of wiring and gas systems.

scdf.title: Fire Safety & Service Directory
scdf.desc: Access Singapore's official Fire Safety services, including guides, and downloadable emergency resources etc.

fss.title: Fire Protection Consultation
fss.desc: Explore local providers offering fire alarms, suppression systems, safety inspections, and consultancy services.

aid.title: CPR & First Aid
aid.description: This guide teaches you how to respond in the first critical minutes of an emergency. Recognize emergencies, when to call 995, hands-only CPR, how to use an AED, and basics.

aid1.label: Life-Saving Skill
aid1.text: Immediate CPR can double or triple survival in cardiac arrest.

aid2.label: Stabilize Condition
aid2.text: Basic care limits bleeding, shock, and deterioration before help arrives.

aid3.label: Quick Response
aid3.text: Knowing what to do reduces hesitation during critical minutes.

aid4.label: Public Safety
aid4.text: More trained bystanders means faster help in crowded places.

aid5.label: Emergency Confidence
aid5.text: Practice builds calm decision-making under pressure.

items.aid1: Enrol in CPR and First Aid courses from recognised providers.
items.aid2: Stock with bandages, antiseptic wipes, gloves, and CPR mask.
items.aid3: Save SCDF (995) and ambulance contacts in your phone.
items.aid4: Learn where Automated External Defibrillators are in your area.

items.aid7: 30 chest compressions + 2 rescue breaths, or hands-only CPR if untrained.
items.aid8: Follow AED voice prompts until help arrives.

items.aid9: Continue care until professionals take over.
items.aid10: Tell responders what you did and any observations.
items.aid11: Restock your first aid kit immediately.
items.aid12: Reflect on what went well and what to improve.

vwh.title: First Aid Tips
vwh.desc: Explore trusted, step-by-step first-aid procedures for common emergencies—bleeding, choking, burns, fractures.

src1.title: Disaster Safety Education
src1.desc: Access the Singapore Red Cross's official guide to first-aid principles, universal precautions, and the role of a responder.

src2.title: Singapore Guidelines
src2.desc: Delve into the updated local first-aid protocols, including basic cardiac life support and recommendations

sfatc.title: Emergency Steps
sfatc.desc: Learn the simple DRSABCD action plan—Check, Call, Care—forming the foundation of effective emergency response.

kit.title: Emergency Kits
kit.description: A collection of essential supplies and equipment prepared in advance to support individuals and families during unexpected crises such as natural disasters, accidents, or power outages.

kit1.label: Life-Saving Supplies
kit1.text: Water, food, and first aid keep you safe until help is available.

kit2.label: Basic Needs
kit2.text: Lighting, tools, and hygiene items maintain daily function.

kit3.label: Reduces Panic
kit3.text: Prepared items provide reassurance and structure during crises.

kit4.label: Supports Evacuation
kit4.text: Grab-and-go bags speed safe movement if you must leave quickly.

kit5.label: Self-Reliance
kit5.text: Supplies help you manage when services are disrupted.

items.kit1: Minimum 4 litres of water per person per day (for drinking & hygiene).
items.kit2: Canned goods, energy bars, dried fruits, ready-to-eat meals.
items.kit3: Ensure first aid kit is well prepared and not expired.
items.kit4: At least 7 days' supply, plus copies of prescriptions.

items.kit5: Battery-powered or hand-crank radio (for local emergency alerts).
items.kit8: Fully charged power banks (for mobile devices).
items.kit9: Multi-tool or Swiss Army knife - for cutting, repairs, or opening cans.

items.kit11: Warm clothing & blankets - thermal layers, poncho, socks.
items.kit12: Dust masks / N95 respirators - for poor air quality or smoke.
items.kit13: Plastic sheeting & duct tape - temporary shelter or sealing openings.
items.kit14: Personal hygiene items - toothbrush, toothpaste, soap, hand sanitiser, etc.

singhealth.title: Home Emergency Kit
singhealth.desc: Find recommended items every household should pack—from water and food to first-aid supplies.

health.title: Every Home Safety
health.desc: An expert-backed list of essential first-aid supplies and their purposes, including wound care, burns, and basic medications.

scdf.title: Civil Defence Resource Pack
scdf.desc: SCDF's official emergency kit resource including guidance on home preparedness and evacuation essentials.

disease.title: Disease Outbreak
disease.description: Learn how to prevent infection, respond effectively during a disease outbreak, and support recovery efforts. Staying informed and prepared can greatly reduce your risk and help control the spread.

disease1.label: Crowded Spaces
disease1.text: Close contact increases transmission through droplets and aerosols.

disease2.label: Poor Hygiene
disease2.text: Infrequent handwashing and surface cleaning allow pathogens to linger.

disease3.label: Global Travel
disease3.text: Rapid movement introduces new variants and seeds local chains.

disease4.label: Contaminated Sources
disease4.text: Unsafe water or food can spread gastrointestinal infections.

disease5.label: Pathogen Mutation
disease5.text: Variants can become more transmissible or immune-evasive.

items.disease1: Keep vaccinations up to date (e.g., influenza, COVID-19, Hepatitis).
items.disease2: Maintain good personal hygiene—wash hands frequently with soap.
items.disease3: Strengthen immunity through healthy diet, exercise, and rest.
items.disease4: Stock basic health supplies—masks, thermometer, hand sanitiser.

items.disease5: Wear masks in crowded or high-risk settings.
items.disease7: Disinfect frequently touched surfaces at home and work.
items.disease8: Avoid sharing personal items like utensils or towels.

items.disease9: Continue practising good hygiene to prevent resurgence.
items.disease10: Attend follow-up health checks if recommended.
items.disease11: Support community vaccination and awareness programmes.
items.disease12: Stay updated on post-outbreak public health guidance.

ncis.title: Ongoing Outbreaks
ncis.desc: Stay informed with current infectious disease outbreaks in Singapore. Includes updates on active cases, and alerts etc.

cdas.title: Infectious Disease Bulletin
cdas.desc: Access the latest official disease surveillance data from weekly bulletins released by the CDA.

ncis2.title: Pandemic Framework
ncis2.desc: Learn about Singapore's strategic pandemic preparedness framework—how our systems detect, respond to, and recover from large-scale disease threats.

cdas2.title: Hospital Outbreak Response
cdas2.desc: Understand how public hospitals activate outbreak response mode—including infection control and scaling operations to manage disease surges.

earthquake.title: Earthquake
earthquake.description: Even though Singapore is not located on a major fault line, tremors from regional earthquakes can still be felt. Being prepared helps you stay calm and act quickly when the ground shakes.

earthquake1.label: Tectonic Plate
earthquake1.text: Stress accumulates along plate boundaries until it releases suddenly.

earthquake2.label: Subduction Zones
earthquake2.text: One plate dives beneath another, generating powerful quakes.

earthquake3.label: Volcanic Activity
earthquake3.text: Magma movement and eruptions can trigger seismic shaking.

earthquake4.label: Fault Slippage
earthquake4.text: Sudden movement along faults releases energy as seismic waves.

earthquake5.label: Aftershocks
earthquake5.text: Smaller quakes follow as the crust readjusts after a main event.

items.earthquake1: Drop, Cover, Hold On - Get under sturdy furniture and protect your head.
items.earthquake2: Stay Away from Glass - Keep clear of windows and mirrors.
items.earthquake3: Do Not Use Lifts - Use stairs only after shaking stops.
items.earthquake4: Stay Indoors Until Safe - Avoid rushing outside during shaking.
items.earthquake5: Turn Off Utilities - If possible, shut off gas and electricity.
items.earthquake6: Remain Calm - Reassure those around you, especially children.

items.earthquake7: Move to Open Space - Away from buildings, trees, and power lines.
items.earthquake8: Avoid Bridges & Overpasses - They may be unstable.
items.earthquake9: Stay Low - Drop to the ground to avoid being knocked over.
items.earthquake10: Follow Official Guidance - Listen to emergency broadcasts.

items.earthquake11: Check for injuries - Provide first aid if needed.
items.earthquake12: Inspect for hazards - Watch for gas leaks or electrical damage.
items.earthquake13: Be alert for aftershocks - They can be as dangerous.
items.earthquake14: Report structural damage - Notify relevant authorities.

nlb.title: Earthquake Awareness Feature
nlb.desc: Explore Earthquake-focused books and resources to deepen your understanding of seismic safety and preparedness.

aa.title: Infectious Disease Bulletin
aa.desc: Practice and learn about the basic guide on steps to take if you are caught in one even you are in a “safe” place for now.

heatstroke.title: Heat Stroke
heatstroke.description: Prolonged exposure to high temperatures can lead to heat-related illnesses, including heat stroke, which is a life-threatening condition. Learn how to stay safe and protect yourself during extreme heat events.

heat1.label: High Ambient Temperature
heat1.text: Extreme environmental heat increases the body's core temperature beyond safe levels.

heat2.label: High Humidity
heat2.text: Excessive humidity reduces the body's ability to cool down through sweating.

heat3.label: Prolonged Sun Exposure
heat3.text: Spending extended periods under direct sunlight without shade increases the risk of heat exhaustion.

heat4.label: Dehydration
heat4.text: Insufficient fluid intake limits the body's cooling mechanisms and accelerates overheating.

heat5.label: Poor Ventilation
heat5.text: Lack of airflow in hot environments traps heat and makes cooling difficult.

items.heat-01: Check daily weather forecasts and heat advisories from NEA.
items.heat-02: Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of water, even if you're not thirsty.
items.heat-03: Wear lightweight, light-colored, and loose-fitting clothing.
items.heat-04: Plan outdoor activities in the early morning or late evening when temperatures are lower.

items.heat-05: Stay indoors in cool or air-conditioned environments whenever possible.
items.heat-06: Use hats, umbrellas, and sunscreen when outdoors to reduce heat exposure.
items.heat-07: Take frequent breaks and rest in shaded areas when outdoors.
items.heat-08: Avoid strenuous physical activity during peak heat hours.

items.heat-09: Watch for symptoms like dizziness, rapid heartbeat, nausea, or confusion — seek medical help immediately if present.
items.heat-10: Cool the body using wet towels, fans, or ice packs while waiting for medical attention.

wsh.title: Heat Stress Management
wsh.desc: Heat stress must not be overlooked, and you should take the necessary measures to protect yourself from heat-related risks.

mom.title: Heat Stress in the Workplace
mom.desc: Learn about heat stroke symptoms, first-aid response, and prevention strategies in workplace.

health.title: Types and Symptoms
health.desc: The weather’s getting hotter but it’s not marathoners or extreme sports enthusiasts who are catching the attention of doctors.
